net.sourceforge.waters.model.module

Interface EdgeProxy

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Proxy
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    EdgeElement

    public interface EdgeProxy
extends Proxy

    An edge in a graph.

    The transitions between the states of a finite-state machine are represented as edges between the nodes of a graph. These edges are directed, i.e., they can be considered as arrows that link two nodes (NodeProxy), called the source and target. In addition, each edge has an associated set of labels that represent the events for the transition. Each edge can have several labels in its label block (LabelBlockProxy), and each label will produce its own transition when the graph is translated into a finite-state machine.

    The way how an edge is to be rendered graphically is stored in separate geometry objects.

    Author:
    Robi Malik

    • Method Detail

      • getSource

        NodeProxy getSource()
        Gets the source node of this edge.

      • getTarget

        NodeProxy getTarget()
        Gets the target node of this edge.

      • getLabelBlock

        LabelBlockProxy getLabelBlock()
        Gets the label block of this edge. The label block contains a list of labels, each representing one event and therefore one transition in the automaton obtained from this graph.

      • getGuardActionBlock

        GuardActionBlockProxy getGuardActionBlock()

      • getGeometry

        SplineGeometryProxy getGeometry()
        Gets the rendering information for this edge.
        Returns:
        A spline geometry object containing the control points for the edge, or null if the edge is rendered as a straight line. The spline geometry does not contain the start and end points of the edge, as these can be obtained from the position of the source and target nodes, or the #getStartPoint() and #getEndPoint() methods.

      • getStartPoint

        PointGeometryProxy getStartPoint()
        Gets the rendering information for the start point of this edge. For most edges, the location of the start point is the position of the source node. But in some cases, namely if the source node is a group node (GroupNodeProxy), an alternative start position may be specified.
        Returns:
        A point geometry object defining an alternative start point, or null if the start point is obtained from the position of the source node.

      • getEndPoint

        PointGeometryProxy getEndPoint()
        Gets the rendering information for the end point of this edge. For most edges, the location of the end point is the position of the target node. But in some cases, namely if the target node is a group node (GroupNodeProxy), an alternative end position may be specified. This only makes sense in a nondeterministic graph.
        Returns:
        A point geometry object defining an alternative end point, or null if the end point is obtained from the position of the target node.
